content: hey @Santiago Pastorino, @simulacrum, and @Wesley Wiser , lets talk here about what we should change in our processes to avoid a repeat occurrence of the issues that arose here.
hm this one seemed to be fine, I was talking about the other stable nom
and discussed a bit here https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/131828-t-compiler/topic/putting.20stable-noms.20on.20release.20radar
oh did I get confused? let me see
If I understand correctly, PR #73613 got into the current beta via the natural train process
but we did not realize that it wasn't in the previous beta
I guess that's good to discuss too -- I had a different concern too
because it missed that train by some number of hours (which, in our world, is a near miss)
(with the track caller stable nom)
I see
but that concern I feel like I have a viable solution for, whereas this one I don't
I suppose this topic could/should be a retrospective on both PR's
(for that one, the plan is to open #t-release streams on all stable-noms, so that we can plan to include them in artifacts)
For PR #73613, @Wesley Wiser had said that maybe we should, as a standard process, just review all the PR's that land in nightly 24 hours after the train leaves
and evaluate whether they should be beta-nominated
Hm. So I personally think it'd be easier to just beta-nominate anything that may need backporting in the week of the release, regardless of when it lands
if it gets included by virtue of landing quickly enough, no problem, backport is trivial
I guess that's my point: Why didn't we know that this needed backporting?
Was it because the issue was not properly tagged?
I note that @oli removed the beta-nom here https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/73613#event-3471714378
I guess that's because it wasn't in that beta?
Maybe we need beta-1.45-nom or something
(it is a frequent point of confusion which beta things are targeting around release weeks)
I don't remember why I changed this. I should comment on such actions :confused:
hmm, yes at that same time @oli also revised the tags on issue #73609
@oli I don't think this is entirely your fault: You said at least that you were trying it out in the playground
okay so this seems like an entirely understandable error
but is there any reasonable way to avoid it in the future?
24 hour window feels like a partial fix at best
For example: some way to run the beta release against just the regression test suite on the nightly channel
If we had such a test suite... yes, we could probably make that happen
where the idea is that the regression test suite will contain only things that should work on the beta
right, the problem there is that we don't have proper metadata to isolate just those tests
Maybe we should actually make sure that all regression-from-stable-to-nightly are confirmed as fixed on beta before being closed
that's probably a more reasonable approach
(I guess only in release week? Obviously many are just fixed on nightly)
How many tests do we add during each release cycle?
how much work would it be to test the current nightly test suite using the beta compiler before a stable release?
we could, as standard operating procedure, backport any tests added for regression-stable-to-nightly to the beta channel
I guess we expect that to always work, right?
since otherwise it's a stable-to-beta regression

lcnr said:

how much work would it be to test the current nightly test suite using the beta compiler before a stable release?

a problem with this is that the nightly test suite will be exercising features that aren't in beta yet
that's why I was careful up above to say that we needed to isolate just the regression tests
yeah, but doing it once might be simple enough to check manually
I don't know about that. It will be a pain to review all the failing tests
I think it wouldn't be too hard to pull out any tests added and include them in backports, presuming we had a list of candidates and asked authors to split them into separate commits
I do worry that backporting tests will be some amount of labor for a problem that is quite rare
if they're in their own commits it is not that much work, so long as we do not go through t-compiler nomination process
@simulacrum hmm, you know, we don't necessarily have to have them be separate commits; we can just look at git diff for src/test for all such issues tagged regression-stable-to-nightly, right?
oh yeah there's no way we'd want to go through T-compiler nomination for this
...cherry-picking diffs is a lot harder than just passing a hash to git cherry-pick
I was thinking a script would do the cherry-picking of diffs
maybe
not sure -- seems somewhat hard
okay yeah thinking on it more, it may be harder than I appreciate
since its not always easy to go from a line in the diff to the issue that its PR was fixing (to find the associated label)
and also, the tests one adds for a PR, even a regression PR, are not always regression tests
so okay
Lets instead try to encourage people to put such tests into their own commits
and maybe have some keyword/tag that should be in the commit message?
e.g. backportable-test or something?
seems good
the problem there is that you cannot change a commit message after the fact
while we may want to add this metadata to commits that already exist, during PR review
does github let you add metadata to commits that we could query here?
/me goes to look
We can open an issue per release that you post the commit hash and issue# in
you can also do the git note thing but that seems hard
hmm yes okay that might be good
(the issue per release, that is)
and, to be clear: git cherry-pick cannot be told to only apply a subset of the commit, namely the stuff under src/test in the diff?
not to my knowledge, and regardless as you mentioned you might be adding non-regression tests too
I think the hardest bit here is telling people to do this
right, I'm giving up on automating this
(I can't imagine us not missing anything with the hundreds of PRs we have per week, realistically)
Sorry, reading the scrollback now...
Is there a set schedule for when beta gets branched?
sort of
https://forge.rust-lang.org/release/process.html#promote-master-to-beta-t-2-days-tuesday
but that can happen basically whenever on that Tuesday, and if something is wonky in a given week we might delay
(e.g., if their are toolstate regressions)
Ok, gotcha
I guess the official workflow for this is as follows: https://jasonrudolph.com/blog/2009/02/25/git-tip-how-to-merge-specific-files-from-another-branch/
namely, git checkout pr-branch src/test

I think @simulacrum's suggestion of "over tagging" to make sure we don't miss beta backports seems good to me. Obviously that's going to be a manual process and we'd only want to do it right around release week, but I think it would still be a step up from what we're doing now.
sorry, "over tagging" ?
Would probably be worth adding an agenda item the week before the release to remind people to tag PRs.
https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/131828-t-compiler/topic/retrospective.20on.20backport.20nomination.20for.20PR.20.2373613/near/205494540
but would that have resolved this issue?
there was a lack of clarity about whether a backport was needed
Hmm perhaps not
https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/73609#issuecomment-647685084
Looks like many of us were confused by which versions were affected.
I guess bisection is the right thing, sort of, but more of "this is broken on X Y Z versions"
another thought I just had
i.e., more automated than people manually trying to check and getting things misclicked and such
As soon as a regression-stable-to-nightly bug is filed
we immediately make a test and backport it to beta
high-work in some sense (branch + write a test and commit + PR + review)
though that might be attacking a different problem
but it... could be the right idea
often we don't have a MCVE until the fix is found
its true, our infrastructure doesn't make this as trivial as I make it sound
perhaps because we should have a lower bar for adding tests? but then again, our test suite is a source of CI slowness, right?
I'm going to stop brainstorming about this and go work on other stuff for a while
Well, I think we would generally want a test anyway so backporting it shouldn't cause a lot of bloat in the test suite.
well that doesn't eliminate ~any of those steps, right?
it's just "small patches are always greatly outweighed by the metawork"
(also why we e.g. don't tend to allow big PRs fixing typos)
Imagine a one click way to say "Take this playground link, turn it into a test and post a PR for it."
the review time is still killer though
we could just ... not review the test
Yes
I guess that was what I was thinking of when I said "a lower bar "
the risk there is that the test doesn't actually test it
unreviewed is a very low bar. :)
but that seems "fine"
so I think the ask is probably that automation
we have that already to some extent with glacier
(well, we've been fixing bugs in it for what feels like this whole year)

There's also some non-obvious things with our testing infra. Just because it fails on the playgroud doesn't mean we can turn that into a test exactly. You might need to tweak things for or exclude various targets (32 bit or platforms some such).
right. @rustbot make-beta-test-from-playground <link>
@Wesley Wiser sure. But presumably if a PR passes the CI, then its okay?
@Wesley Wiser yeah, though some of that can be resolved in PR targeting beta -- i.e., beta rollup
Also if you're "Building" on the playground, that's now what our test infra does.
we just need to be more cautious about r+'ing that immediately
I found a test we added last week that passed only because main() didn't call anything which generated the ICE.

Wesley Wiser said:

Also if you're "Building" on the playground, that's now what our test infra does.

I didn't understand this
When you "Build" on the playground you get --crate-type lib but our test suite does --crate-type bin
the reference to the playground was just meant to be a place to get the source code
Gotcha
I see, yes, the playground's context is different from the CI's
I just figure its easier to reference playground links and extract source from them, versus e.g. scraping github comments
FWIW, I wouldn't have an issue doing this manually for regression-stable-to-* issues.

Wesley Wiser said:

FWIW, I wouldn't have an issue doing this manually for regression-stable-to-* issues.

as in, you don't think its worth investing in infra to automate it?
I think that would be great but I don't want the lack of automation to stop us from finding a fix to the process issue.
I agree with that
Another option would be to do an "ice breaker" like team and ping people to crowd source it
It's an easy contribution once there's a fix with a test case.

(and I'm still not sure we've identified a fix to the process issue. In part because we don't know 100% why the process failed here; we know this was nominated and unnominated, and we aren't certain why.)
I think the un-nomination was a result of my comment here https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/73609#issuecomment-647685084
right, but your logic seemed reasonable, no?
Yeah
So it seems @oli was right to begin with but we don't know how
Was it something where the nightly-t-beta lift happened right on June 21st or something?
That was a Sunday which doesn't sound right per the above timeline
Is there anyway to find out when the beta branch was updated?
That seems like a critical piece of info we don't have currently
well no but you can tell when it branched
which release are we talking about? 1.45?
Yeah
eeaf497b2a6bc065874e3d3367b1f3023c5bb3d3 is I believe when 1.45.0 and master diverged
found via git merge-base --fork-point origin/master 1.45.0
yeah manually checking that seems right
I'm very confused then
That commit is from June 2 but the broken commit landed on June 21
I'm trying to figure out if we just stable-approved something that isn't actually a bug on stable...
We got a bug report about stable though...
maybe we backported the thing that broke it?
wow I wasn't aware of the comment thread on issue #74739
yeah :/
I can't even find the offending commit on stable
Yeah, it was the on the front page of /r/rust
Huh
I should stop clicking through GH's commit log and just use git
Okay I'm re-invested now in figuring this out. :)
Oh wow
So c06876c90437c7eecd1dc246d3515d6211397f16 and 2f49d554ff1afd1633a01d6b84192ad0147d9097 are not in 1.45 it seems?
stable is the right branch for 1.45 right?
but we didn't revert them..
We wouldn't have removed those commits and push -f or something right?
no
1.45.0 is the stable tag
So yeah, they're not there
Oh true
but they're not there
wth
so either we misdiagnosed the cause and the fix just happens to work or something... is weird
I mean, it's possible there was a different similar bug that this also fixed
But that would be a totally unknown bug
And since RalfJ found this bug literally hours after the bad commit landed, it seems kind of unlikely.
hm okay now I want to re-confirm that we did fix this in 1.45.1 (yet to be released)
You should double check me but I did test the reported issue when I made the patch.
yeah ... I feel like we even included tests?
oli had added some tests for the original issue
I have a TODO to add a test with the specific test case from the stable bug report.
okay the patch is fixed in 1.45.1
er, bug
but we don't yet know what caused it in 1.45.0 right?
since the bad commits don't seem to be in it
Right
I guess we could bisect
yeah i'm going to try to do that (bisect) on my machine now
hm so the issue repro bisects to https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/commit/3fe4dd2dda2826643c4ce4ee7307707a90e08d25 for me
1.44 definitely does not have the issue and 1.45 definitely does. I just checked.
I am not sure if that's because 3fe4dd enabled some code (that would've been broken previously) or not, though
and that commit, 3fe4dd, does appear to be in 1.45 and not in 1.44
Perhaps oli managed to trigger the existing issue on the (then) beta branch and we didn't realize that meant there was an existing issue.
perhaps, yeah
okay, so in the end, I think we can conclude that #74739 was in fact not a duplicate of #73609, right?
because that claim was, AFAICT, a big part of what led to confusion today
maybe? I'm not sure :/
hey guys, sorry, I was busy most of the day and missed all this discussion
going to read the thread but skimming it a bit I'm not sure if we did conclude something about what should we do to avoid such situations

@simulacrum kind of unrelated but a thing I was mentioning during the meeting is https://calendar.google.com/calendar/embed?src=mozilla.com_ts4qudb88i0tbjef8rche4a6v4%40group.calendar.google.com&ctz=America%2FMontevideo
this is the calendar I'm using for Rust releases
unsure from where did I got but is something that I've been following since ages and I thought it was something official
yeah I know nothing about it, seems like some mozilla thing
it would be nice to know from an official source when releases happen

simulacrum said:

yeah I know nothing about it, seems like some mozilla thing

would be reasonable to create an official one? or how should I know that a release happens ahead of time?
So there are two possible conclusions I can draw after this retrospective
Let's discuss release scheduling elsewhere
1. These two issues were not duplicates. So, I do not assign anyone blame in terms of "why wasn't this fix backported"; it wasn't like we overlooked a known bug
however
if you read the comment thread for PR #73613
it seems clear that there was a big gaping hole in the const propagator
at least, @RalfJ expressed concern about how the bug being fixed #73613 managed to get in there

simulacrum said:

(with the track caller stable nom)

do you have a link for that? (the thread ended being all about the constprop problem, but still I wonder what the other one even is about -- nothing here seems to link to a PR/issue)

pnkfelix said:

it seems clear that there was a big gaping hole in the const propagator

yes. and we thought the hole was opened by #71911 but it seems actually the hole was present already since #71953 (higher number but landed earlier)?
@oli described the latter as being "moderately scared" by the change^^
uh, okay, something is odd -- the diff view at https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/71911/files includes the diff of https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/71953/files?

or parts of it at least:

  • https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/71911/files#diff-9e103702275cbef342c2decd3395bf3bL854
  • https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/71953/files#diff-9e103702275cbef342c2decd3395bf3bL828
ah no it just looks very similar (to someone not at all familiar with that code)
@RalfJ I was referring to https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/74764 with the track caller discussions

I'm not sure if this is still relevant, but very early in this discussion it was mentioned that there is a lot of confusion as to which beta things are targeting around release weeks. Could this be solved by either raging which beta the thing is meant for or even just mentioning in a comment on the issue/PR which beta something related to (maybe at the same point as when the beta-relevant tag is added)?

simulacrum said:

RalfJ I was referring to https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/74764 with the track caller discussions

thanks! I added a corresponding test to Miri, just to be sure.
is there any reason https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/74739 is still open? should we add this as a testcase to master?
https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/75449
